sense.def: something that you do often and regularly, almost without knowing that you are doing it
dictionaryExamples: healthy eating habits
I always buy the same toothpaste out of  habit.
I'm trying not to get into the habit of watching TV all the time.
He can't break the habit of putting sugar in his coffee.
They weren't in the habit of recycling.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In your last letter you ask[ed] me about my shopping habits and my clothes. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: something that you often do that is bad for you or is annoying
dictionaryExamples: He has some really annoying/nasty habits.
I picked up  some  bad eating habits from my roommate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With more free time and more money to spend than ever, shopping is a great activity, but when this creates bad habits [such] as overspending, [it] could lead to serious problems. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the natural environment of an animal or plant
dictionaryExamples: We want to see lions in their natural habitat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These snakes and wild cats are able to live in the wild, as the forests in Denmark are like their natural habitat. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: hard balls of ice that fall from the sky like rain
dictionaryExamples: Hail the size of golf balls dented my car in the storm.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the past, a very cold winter and hail would destroy the crops and kill hundreds of families; and, moreover, people had little protection against the attacks of wild animals. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If it hails, small, hard pieces of frozen rain fall from the sky.
dictionaryExamples: It hailed for a few minutes this morning.

sense.def: to call or wave to someone to get their attention
dictionaryExamples: You wait here while I hail a cab.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you see a car or a bus or some other vehicle, just hail them and ask for help. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to publicly praise or show approval for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Heppner has been hailed as one of the finest tenors in the operatic world today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But, fortunately, these Olympic Games in 2004 were hailed as a success by everyone. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the thin, thread-like parts that grow on your head
dictionaryExamples: curly/straight hair
blond/dark/fair/gray/red hair
She has long/short/shoulder-length brown hair.
I'm going to get my hair cut.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has long and dark hair, she has a big eyes, she is a serious girl. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: one or more of the thin thread-like parts that grow on a person's or animal's skin
dictionaryExamples: He's starting to get a few gray hairs now.
My black skirt was covered in cat hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then he appeared: a [fat], middle-aged man with only a few hairs on his head. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to be very relaxed  and enjoy yourself a lot
dictionaryExamples: I'd love to see Clare let her hair down for once.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thrace hosts every year, festivals and carnivals where all the family can let [their] hair down and have fun. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when someone cuts your hair, or the style in which it has been cut
dictionaryExamples: to get a haircut
I really need a haircut.
I like your new haircut.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You two have the same haircut, the same complexion but not the same attitude, which is good. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a person who cuts people's hair and puts it into a style
dictionaryExamples: Who's your hairdresser?
I have a four o'clock appointment with the hairdresser.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to suggest a new time to meet you on Tuesday because I've got a hairdresser appointment at ten a.m. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: a piece of electrical equipment for drying your hair with hot air
dictionaryExamples: Did you pack a hair dryer?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The comfortable rooms you are offering, do they have showers, hair dryers, [and] such facilities? First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a person who cuts people's hair and puts it into a style
dictionaryExamples: Her hairstylist gave her a short cut that's easy to care for.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All the women before the wedding usually go to the hairstylist. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: costing half the usual price
dictionaryExamples: I got half-price tickets for the show tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It will cost [$]215, [which is] almost half-price. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: for half the usual price
dictionaryExamples: If you pay one full fare, the second person can travel at half price.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to sell my "English Grammar" book, it's a great book, simple to read, not very used, just the right book for you, and I sell it at less than half price; INCREDIBLE!! Key English Test; A2; Italian

sense.def: a large room or building where meetings, concerts, and other events happen
dictionaryExamples: Her dream is to perform at Carnegie  Hall.
a concert/lecture hall
the students' dining hall
There's an important meeting at the town hall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can make the concert hall look more attractive. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: a room or passage in a building that leads to other rooms
dictionaryExamples: an entrance hall
Children are not allowed to run in the school halls.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I left it in the hall. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: meat from a pig's back or upper leg
dictionaryExamples: a ham sandwich
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every day for bre[a]kfast we have bread with ham. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Polish

sense.def: a tool with a heavy, metal part at the top that you use to hit nails into something
dictionaryExamples: You will need a hammer and some nails.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I gave her tools because I [did] not know [a] hammer from [a] screwdriver and she cleaned four plugs. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: the part of your body on the end of your arm that has fingers and a thumb
dictionaryExamples: Take your hands out of your pockets!
You have to hold my hand when we cross the street.
They walked by, holding hands.
Hold your fork in your left hand and your knife in your right hand.
"Congratulations!" she said and shook my hand/shook hands with me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hi Sabrina The party was good. I forgot my phone in your house - I had it [in] my pocket, then it was in my hand and then I put [it] on [a] table in the kitchen. Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: some help, especially to do something practical
dictionaryExamples: Could you give me a hand with these suitcases?
I think Matthew might need a hand with his homework.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She asked me to give her a hand. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: done or made by a person instead of a machine
dictionaryExamples: This sweater has to be washed by hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I used to remember my mother washing our clothes by hand, but for me it is just a matter of throwing the clothes into the washing machine and pressing a few buttons. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

blocks.phrase: on the one hand . . . on the other hand

sense.def: used when you are comparing two different ideas or opinions
dictionaryExamples: On the one hand, computer games develop many skills, but on the other, they mean kids don't get enough exercise.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the one hand, I know from my experience that it's much easier in life if you know more about everything, but on the other hand, I'd say that if someone [had given] me a chance (when I was kid) to study what I enjoy[ed],  probably I'd have more possibility to develop my skills. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: holding each other's hand
dictionaryExamples: The children walked hand in hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hand in hand they got off the train and she felt that her decision to leave was the best decision she had ever [made] in her life. First Certificate in English; B2; Slovak

sense.def: If two things go hand in hand, they exist together and are connected with each other.
dictionaryExamples: Prosperity goes hand in hand with investment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Traffic and pollution go hand in hand. International English Language Testing System; C1; German

sense.def: near in time or space
dictionaryExamples: Teachers are always close at hand to give help to any child who needs it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I haven't had any lectures in English, but now and then there are lectures in English at the University so you need to understand the spoken language with no dictionary at hand. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: to be in someone's control or care
dictionaryExamples: The matter is now in the hands of my lawyer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The future of our country is in the hands of these two men who are so different and who can't stand each other. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: being cared for or dealt with by someone skilled
dictionaryExamples: The project is in safe hands - Jan has lots of experience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has also been trained as a lifeguard so the residents of your hotel would probably be in safe hands. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: without using a weapon or tool
dictionaryExamples: He broke the log in two with his bare hands!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I learned how to milk a cow, with my bare hands. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: near to someone or something, and ready to help or be used when necessary
dictionaryExamples: Extra supplies will be on hand, in case they are needed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From their point of view, they can always have you on hand whenever they need help, which is the most important part in their formative years. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: to find something
dictionaryExamples: Do you know where I can lay my hands on a pair of scissors?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And as long as we remain unable to distinguish between needs and desires, amassing material possessions to gratify our fleeting caprices or alleviate our frustrations, we are bound to be trapped in the illusion that only by laying our hands on the desired goods can we obtain happiness and peace of mind. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: being worked on or dealt with now
dictionaryExamples: Don't worry – we have the situation  in hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Miss Kenton keeps asking Stevens whether everything is in hand and whether her help is required. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to be in a stronger position than someone else so that you control a situation
dictionaryExamples: Government troops are gradually gaining the upper hand over the rebels.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Humans vs. machines - who has the upper hand? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to become difficult to control
dictionaryExamples: It was the end of week and the children were getting a little out of hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: A few solutions can prevent this problem from getting out of hand. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: permission to make your own decisions about how you want to do something
dictionaryExamples: The students were given a free hand as far as designing their projects was concerned.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But unlike my parents, I wouldn't give my children a free hand in solving their problems. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to be very busy
dictionaryExamples: Shelley has her hands full with three kids under 5.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This very fact made my father work [like] a slave, as he was the only breadwinner at home, my mother having her hands full with us four. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

blocks.phrase: take the law into your own hands

sense.def: to do something illegal in order to punish someone because you know that the law will not punish that person
dictionaryExamples: The police did nothing about the thefts, so they took the law into their own hands.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, locals are scared to death, leading to their taking the law into their own hands. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to give someone something
dictionaryExamples: She handed him the letter.
He handed the car keys to her.
Could you hand me that book, please?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe you could hand me a paper with several questions I can answer, thus I [would]  cover the work I miss. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

blocks.phrase: you have to hand it to sb

sense.def: used when you want to show that you admire someone
dictionaryExamples: You have to hand it to Mick, he's done a good job on that kitchen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had saved the bu[si]ness, and of course everybody knew it.  Begrudgingly they'd had to hand it to her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

blocks.phrasalVerb: hand sth down or hand down sth

sense.def: to pass possessions or traditions from older people to younger ones
dictionaryExamples: a custom handed down through the generations
This clock was handed down from my great-grandfather to my grandfather, then to my mother, and now to me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The ring is of great significance to me as it was handed down from generation to generation, and I was the lucky one, who inherited it from my grandmother. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

blocks.phrasalVerb: hand in sth or hand sth in

sense.def: to give a piece of written work to a teacher
dictionaryExamples: Have you handed in your homework yet?

blocks.phrasalVerb: hand out sth or hand sth out

sense.def: to give something to each person in a group or place
dictionaryExamples: The teacher asked her to hand out the worksheets.
They stood on the street corner handing out leaflets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I handed out refreshment[s] to the pop group's members during breaks - my friends were so jealous of me! First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

blocks.phrasalVerb: hand  over sb/sth or hand sb/sth over

sense.def: to give someone or something to someone else
dictionaryExamples: The hijacker was handed over to the French police.
They were ordered to hand over their weapons.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the end, we handed them over to the police and we were rewarded. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a game in which players hit a small hard rubber ball against a wall with their hands
dictionaryExamples: We played handball yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last Saturday was my party, it was wonderful.  I played handball in the afternoon, but in the evening I danced. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: describes something that is designed to be held and used easily with one or two hands
dictionaryExamples: a handheld camera/computer/device
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Soon you will be able to access all th[i]s information through your mobile or handheld device. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: a small piece of cloth or soft paper that you use to dry your eyes or nose
dictionaryExamples: She dabbed her eyes with a handkerchief.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We are going to see a dramatic film, Era mio padre, so don't forget your handkerchief. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to deal with something
dictionaryExamples: I thought he handled the problem/situation very well.
If you can't handle the job I'll get someone else to do it.
Who handles the marketing in your company?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He couldn't handle it and started to run in the rain, crying, thinking. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to touch, hold, or pick up something
dictionaryExamples: You must wash your hands before handling food.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In India, people tend to handle food with their hands, I have been told most people eat without cutlery. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: the part of something that you use to hold it or open it
dictionaryExamples: a door handle
I can't pick the kettle up - the handle's too hot.
She turned the handle and slowly opened the door.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I saw my chair, my carpet... and my door handle!... First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a copy of a document that is given to all the people in a class or meeting
dictionaryExamples: On page two of your handout you will find a list of the books that I have referred to during the lecture.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: During our course, I made [an] effort to follow the lectures, [and,] for instance, to check the unknown vocab[ul]ar[y] which appeared in handouts. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: A handsome man is attractive.
dictionaryExamples: She's hoping that she'll meet a tall, dark, handsome stranger.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The main actor is very handsome too. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a large amount of money
dictionaryExamples: a handsome salary
They made a handsome profit on the sale of their house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, from an economic stand-point, it is generally believed that international sports events only serve as a means for TV companies to monopoli[z]e entertainment while turning a handsome profit. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: the way that someone forms the letters when they write with a pen or pencil
dictionaryExamples: His handwriting is impossible to read.
We don't spend as much time teaching handwriting to children anymore.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have pretty bad handwriting as you know from my letters, and with a computer and a printer I can avoid others who read my letters [from being] put off by my handwriting. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: useful or easy to use
dictionaryExamples: a handy container/tool
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Such a possession may be something they use all the time, like a fountain pen for a writer, or a handy camera for a photographer, and they have become "dependent" on them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to be useful at some time in the future
dictionaryExamples: Don't throw those jars away - they might come in handy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There's a washer and a dryer in the basement. I'm sure they'll come in handy with your new bundle of joy and the rest of your lovely bunch. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to fasten or support something at the top leaving the other parts free to move, or to be held in this way
dictionaryExamples: A heavy gold necklace hung around her neck.
Hang your coat and hat on the rack over there.
The curtains hung in thick folds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She kept it in a tiny red bag which hung around her neck like a neckl[ace]. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to kill someone by dropping them with a rope tied around their neck, or to die in this way
dictionaryExamples: He was found guilty and hanged later that year.
The woman tried to hang herself with a sheet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Their childhood was rather unhappy because their father was convicted [of] murder and hanged. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to stay in the air for a long time
dictionaryExamples: Smoke from the campfires hung in the air.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The smog hangs over the cities like a deadly cloud, resulting [in] many health problems like pulmonary d[i]seases and cancer. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If something is or hangs in the balance, nobody knows if it will continue to exist in the future or what will happen to it.
dictionaryExamples: The game hung in the balance until the last seconds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is my firm belief, that unless we make a step towards the development of our town, its future will hang in the balance and we will ultimately pay the price of our short sightedness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to spend time somewhere, usually doing very little
dictionaryExamples: There's nowhere for teenagers to go so they just hang around on street corners.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was great because the whole time I was able to ride my skateboard and hang around with my friends, and I had a lot of fun. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to wait for a short time
dictionaryExamples: Hang on a minute while I see if Steve can come to the phone.
Can you hang on for a little longer until we're finished?
Hang on  - I'll be with you in a minute!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I were you, I would take my job with more calm and I wouldn't be nervous when talking on [the] telephone, hang[ing] on waiting for an answer. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: to spend a lot of time in a place or with someone
dictionaryExamples: We like hanging out at the mall.
I've been hanging out backstage with the band.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, when I hang out with my friends, I love wearing a skirt. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to finish a conversation on the telephone
dictionaryExamples: She said goodbye and hung up.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then he hung up immediately. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

blocks.phrasalVerb: hang up sth or hang sth up

sense.def: to put something, especially a piece of clothing, somewhere where it can hang
dictionaryExamples: You can hang up your jacket over there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first problem I would like to mention is what everybody in our class knows: we have to hang up more signs, which show the way to the reception, because visitors and new students have lots of problems find[ing] it. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to learn how to do something, especially if it is not obvious or simple
dictionaryExamples: I've  never used one of these before. - Don't worry, you'll soon get the hang of it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was quite hard to get the hang of it, as I didn't have any knowledge of English. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If an event or situation happens, it exists or starts to be done, usually by chance.
dictionaryExamples: Were you there when the accident happened?
We can't let a mistake like this happen again.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it happened in his bedroom because I saw some sports clothes and we know he plays basketball. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: to be the result of an action, situation, or event that someone or something experiences
dictionaryExamples: Did you hear what happened to us last night?
What happens if we can't get enough tickets?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In most Czech families dinner [is the] only meal when everybody eat[s] together and talk[s] about everything [t]hat happened to them [during] that day. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Czech

sense.def: to do something by chance
dictionaryExamples: If you happen to see Peter, say "hi" for me.
You don't happen to know her phone number, do you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am certainly more confident and can understand whatever I happen to read in English, which is of course of the utmost importance for my work in this company. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: something that you say in order to introduce a surprising fact
dictionaryExamples: As it happens, her birthday is the day after mine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As it happens, I am currently looking for a computer course for myself and I would like to join one of your courses. International English Language Testing System; C1; Hebrew

sense.def: in a happy way
dictionaryExamples: He was happily married with two young children.
The baby sucked  happily on a corner of her blanket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now we are happily married and I cannot stop thinking what would have happened if I had thrown away the e-mail...? Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: in a way that is very willing
dictionaryExamples: I'd happily offer to help him if I thought it would make any difference.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think young people would happily accept it. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: having a good or lucky result
dictionaryExamples: Happily, the operation was a complete success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Happily, I had met a friend who could take me to school! Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: the feeling of being happy
dictionaryExamples: It was only later in life that she found happiness and peace of mind.
Will you join me in wishing the bride and groom every happiness?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wish you happiness, you deserve it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: feeling, showing, or causing pleasure
dictionaryExamples: She looks so/very happy.
I'm glad you've found someone who makes you happy.
a happy marriage/childhood
Nicole seems a lot happier since she got a new job.
I'm so happy (that) everything is working out for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very happy that I can go [to] college every day and I can see my friends every day. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Croatian

sense.def: something friendly that you say to someone on a special day or holiday
dictionaryExamples: Happy anniversary, darling!
I hope you have a happy birthday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Happy Halloween! Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: willing to do something
dictionaryExamples: I'd be very happy to help, if you need a hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would be very happy to help you with the concert. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: satisfied and not worried
dictionaryExamples: Are you happy with the grades you got this semester?
No one is happy about having to pay more taxes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very happy with my computer. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: behavior that annoys or upsets someone
dictionaryExamples: sexual harassment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, they may be underpaid in comparison to men carrying out the same tasks, are seldom promoted - although they may be better qualified - and sometimes have to endure sexual harassment by their bosses. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: an area of water next to the coast, often protected from the sea by a thick wall, where ships and boats can shelter
dictionaryExamples: Our hotel room overlooked a pretty little fishing harbor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have a large room with a balcony from where I see the harbor and the beach. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: difficult to understand or do
dictionaryExamples: There were some really hard questions on the test.
It's hard being an immigrant.
Her handwriting is very hard to read.
The game gets harder on every new level.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like gram[m]ar. English gram[m]ar is hard for me. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: firm and stiff, and not easy to press or bend
dictionaryExamples: a hard surface
There was a heavy frost last night and the ground is still hard.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have to bring with us three pencils, two hard pencils and one soft. Key English Test; A2; Greek

sense.def: needing or using a lot of physical or mental effort
dictionaryExamples: Go on - give it a good hard push!
It was hard work on the farm, but satisfying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's the perfect place to stay and relax after a week of hard work. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to criticize someone too much, or to treat them unfairly
dictionaryExamples: Don't be too hard on him - he's new to the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's why I was a little hard on you at first. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: full of problems and difficult to deal with
dictionaryExamples: My grandparents had a very hard life.
The past few months must've been really hard for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a really hard time for all of us, but it passed and, I hope, will never come again. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to learn something by experiencing a lot of problems or difficulty
dictionaryExamples: He doesn’t want to take my advice, so I guess he’ll have to learn the hard way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you don't know the past, you're liable to live through it again as instead of deriving the lessons from someone else's experiences, you'll have to learn them the hard way, by trial and error. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to make someone unhappy by causing them problems
dictionaryExamples: Don’t be too hard on her – she’s just learning the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Also it was hard on our family only seeing my father late at night being tired or for a weekend, if he was not on a business-trip. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to criticize someone and make them feel guilty about something they have done
dictionaryExamples: His boss has been giving him a hard time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm not saying that I wasn't normal or anything, I just gave my family a hard time sometimes. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: anger, unhappiness, or lack of trust
dictionaryExamples: I hope you don't have any hard feelings.
I'm sorry it didn't work out, but no hard feelings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were no hard feelings anymore. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: with a lot of physical or mental effort
dictionaryExamples: She tried very hard but she wasn't quite fast enough.
You'll have to work harder if you want to pass this class.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't like to work very hard and very late in [the] classroom and I don't like computer[s]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: with a lot of force
dictionaryExamples: It's been raining hard all day.
She kicked the ball as hard as she could.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was a clo[u]dy day, the wind [was] blow[ing] hard, and the city was quiet. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the part inside a computer that is not removed and that stores very large amounts of information
dictionaryExamples: A virus damaged my hard drive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know, computer prices are getting lower every day and technology is growing so fast so I thought that if I waited more and began saving money, I could buy a new computer with new stuff (better chip, hard drive etc.) in six months time. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: almost not, or only a very small amount
dictionaryExamples: We hardly ever  go to concerts.
I can hardly hear the speaker from here in the back.
The party had hardly started when she left.
He ate hardly anything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've hardly ever called them since I came to this country to study English. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: certainly not
dictionaryExamples: You can hardly expect me to wait around all day for you to get ready.
It's hardly surprising that she's angry at him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And then, although you [have] allowed me to use all your stuff, I hardly think I can touch your computer and the CD player. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a problem or situation that makes you suffer a lot, especially because you are very poor
dictionaryExamples: They have suffered years of financial hardship.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, I have to say that this plan would cause much inconvenience and hardship for our local residents. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; Mandarin

sense.def: the physical and electronic parts of a computer, rather than the programs
dictionaryExamples: We need to include new hardware in our budget.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Computer technology keeps improving all the time and consume[r]s like me and you definitely have to pay our money to keep our personal computer up to date and able to work with new computer software that require[s] [better and better] performance of computer hardware. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: doing a job seriously and with a lot of effort
dictionaryExamples: She's a very hard-working student.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I am suitable for the job because, apart from all [the] above, I am hard-working, well-educated and imaginative. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to hurt someone or damage something
dictionaryExamples: Thankfully, no one was harmed in the accident.
Rare plants and animals are being harmed by the destruction of the rain forests.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But in those places animals were harmed and died easily. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: hurt or damage
dictionaryExamples: Alan would never do anyone any harm.
It will do you no harm to be nice to him.
I'm sorry. I  didn't mean any harm.
Smoking can cause serious harm to the lungs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is true that the car does us harm. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

blocks.phrase: there's no harm in doing sth

sense.def: used to say that something is not a bad thing to do and could possibly have a good effect
dictionaryExamples: I suppose there's no harm in trying.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There is no lack of go[o]d language schools and there is no harm in trying another one the next time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: causing harm
dictionaryExamples: This group of chemicals is known to be harmful to people with asthma.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, books are not harmful to our health as computers sometimes are. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: not able or not likely to cause harm
dictionaryExamples: Most mushrooms are completely/totally harmless, but some are poisonous.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, cars are not as harmless as they look so we must stop using them so much. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: not likely to shock or upset people or to cause problems
dictionaryExamples: Their jokes seemed harmless enough.
Peter might look a bit fierce, but actually he's fairly harmless.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He seemed harmless enough so I decided to take a nap. Suddenly I heard a strange noise and I was terrified to hear his loud voice booming in my ear. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: when people are peaceful and agree with each other, or when different things seem right or suitable together
dictionaryExamples: living together in peace and harmony
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to think my children are going to live in a lovely world where the human being [will] be able to live in peace and harmony with the environment. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a pleasant sound in music, made by playing or singing a group of different notes together
dictionaryExamples: The choir sang in perfect harmony.
Their voices produced beautiful harmonies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having some singing knowledge myself, I can say their performance was excellent: the tune was maintained all through the concert, the r[hyth]m was also carefully kept and the[y] sounded in perfect harmony. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: very cold, dangerous, or unpleasant and difficult to live in
dictionaryExamples: harsh conditions
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, I have been trained for a year in living in harsh conditions. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: cruel, unkind, or unpleasant in a way that seems unfair
dictionaryExamples: harsh criticism/punishment
Taking him out of the game was a bit harsh.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Sorry if I sounded so harsh in the letter but I felt it was important to make these points. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: too strong, bright, loud, etc.
dictionaryExamples: harsh chemicals/lighting
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It only contains herbs and plant extracts so it would not be too harsh a product for the skin and will not destroy the skin's natural defen[s]es. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: in an unkind, strict, or unpleasant way
dictionaryExamples: Violators are being dealt with harshly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am writing in response to a letter published in last week's issue of the newspaper "Society today", in which "An Inspector Calls", is harshly critici[z]ed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: when crops are cut and gathered from fields
dictionaryExamples: the wheat/corn/grape harvest
We had a good/bad/poor harvest this year.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well I can tell you about our annual harvest festival. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: something you wear to cover your head, for fashion or protection
dictionaryExamples: a straw hat
a winter hat
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to wear this hat when I go to [my] grandmother's house. Key English Test; A2; Japanese

sense.def: to dislike someone or something very much
dictionaryExamples: Kelly hates her teacher.
She hated the winter.
I hate it when you do that.
I have always hated speaking in public.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love rock and techno but I hate rap. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: a strong dislike for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Hate and bigotry can only make our lives more difficult.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Feelings of hate and disgust may fill us, but we may love somebody. Many people say that love and hate go together. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: an extremely strong feeling of dislike
dictionaryExamples: What is very clear in these letters is Clark's passionate hatred of his father.
The motive for this shocking attack seems to be racial hatred.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The producers create situations involving different feeling[s] [such] as love, hatred, anger, fear,... Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: to pull something somewhere slowly and with difficulty
dictionaryExamples: They hauled the piano into the living room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "When I'm finished, you can jump whenever you like. Remember to hold on to each other, and we'll haul you up when it's all over." Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: an amount of something, often something that has been stolen or that is owned illegally
dictionaryExamples: a haul of arms/drugs
She got a huge haul of gifts at Christmas.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because of the loud noise of the running engine, she wasn't aware of the man behind her grabbing the smaller bag and turning round ready to escape with his haul. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If a ghost haunts a place, it appears there often.
dictionaryExamples: They say that the house is haunted by the soldier's ghost.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The castle] is 500 years old, and it is said to be haunted by a lady ghost. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: If an unpleasant memory or feeling haunts you, you think about or feel it often.
dictionaryExamples: Fighting in Vietnam was an experience that would haunt him for the rest of his life.
Thirty years after the fire he is still haunted by images of death and destruction.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And so John remained alone, haunted by the terrible loss. First Certificate in English; B2; Romanian

sense.def: used with the past participle of another verb to form the present and past perfect tenses
dictionaryExamples: Have you seen Jake?
He hasn't visited us yet.
I've met his wife before.
It would have been better to tell the truth.
He's been working in Denver for two years now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Jo, Sorry I haven't written sooner. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to need to do something or be forced to do something
dictionaryExamples: I've got to buy some new shoes.
Do we have to finish this today?
They've had to change their plans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is important for me because I have to study for my History test. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: used when you are telling someone how to do something
dictionaryExamples: You have to wait for the green light and then record your voice.
You've got to type in your name, then your password.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To get to my house, you have to get the bus [number] 30 to town, [and] there you have to get the bus [number] 15 to Spring Bank. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say that you feel certain that something is true or will happen
dictionaryExamples: Interest rates have to come down at some point.
There's got to be a better way of doing this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There has to be a solution to this. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to own or possess
dictionaryExamples: They have a big house.
He has blue eyes.
She has a lot of experience.
Do you have time to finish the report today?
I've got two brothers.
He's got a degree in journalism.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had [a] big house in Somalia, now I hav[e] [a]  small house. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Somali

sense.def: If you have a particular illness, you suffer from it.
dictionaryExamples: I have a cold.
Have you ever had the measles?
Dad has a headache.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know you had [the] flu. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: to eat or drink something
dictionaryExamples: I had a turkey sandwich for lunch.
Can I have a drink of water?
Let's have a snack before the movie.
When are we having dinner?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have dinner [at] 5 pm. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; French

sense.def: to give birth to a baby
dictionaryExamples: Elaine had a baby girl yesterday.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And later, we can go [to] Mary's house, because she has had a baby, and I would like to see her. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: have fun/a good time/a problem, etc.

sense.def: to experience something
dictionaryExamples: Have a nice day!
We had a great time in Montreal.
We had a few problems finding the house.
Did you have any luck finding a present for Annie?
I had a bad dream.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We played a lot of games and had fun. Key English Test; A2; Singhalese

sense.def: used with nouns to say that someone does or will do something
dictionaryExamples: We have a committee meeting next week.
Anita is going to have a birthday party!
I have a piano lesson at two o'clock.
Try having a conversation with him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last weekend, I had a[n] argument with my parents, and I was angry, so I left my home and [took] a walk outside. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: to think of a question/idea/plan, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Do you have any other ideas?
Mr. Grant, I have a question.
I'm glad you have a plan.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have a question for you! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to pay someone to do something for you
dictionaryExamples: We had our washing machine repaired.
We're having the house painted next month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My mother is having her car repaired. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If you have something stolen/taken, etc., someone takes something that belongs to you.
dictionaryExamples: She had her car stolen last week.
I had my purse taken.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me over the phone that he had arrived in London with his wife, but shortly after the arrival, he had ha[d] his wallet stolen in the underground station. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: to cause something to be in  a particular state
dictionaryExamples: He had dinner ready by the time we got home.
We had the tent up within ten minutes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had everything ready in case of an emergency or a chaos situation. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: used to say that someone is holding something, or that someone or something is with them
dictionaryExamples: He had a pen in his hand.
She had a little boy with her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maria had the phone in her hand. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to not know
dictionaryExamples: "Where's Tina?" "I have no idea."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have no idea about how his children are. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: If you have someone over/to stay, etc., you arrange for someone to visit you in your home.
dictionaryExamples: We had David and Amy over for dinner last week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It happened when I had a friend over for dinner. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to be completely unable to guess, understand, or deal with something
dictionaryExamples: I don't have a clue what you're talking about.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I just don't know which clothes to take with me because I don't have a clue about the Scottish weather. First Certificate in English; B2; German

blocks.phrase: have nothing to do with sb/sth

sense.def: to have no connection or influence with someone or something
dictionaryExamples: He made his own decision - I had nothing to do with it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course, I tried to explain [to] him that I had nothing to do with the vanishing of the cake but he didn't trust me. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: have nothing to do with sb

sense.def: If something has nothing to do with you, you have no good reason to know about it or be involved with it.
dictionaryExamples: Stop asking questions. This has nothing to do with you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The party was horrible: the guests were all talking about things that had nothing to do with me. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: to have a reason not to like someone or something
dictionaryExamples: Ellen doesn't have anything against bowling either, so let's go!
I have nothing against him personally, I just don't think he's the right man for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you have nothing against taking public transport, I suggest taking a bus. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to ask, arrange for, or pay  someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: We need to have someone fix the radiator in the bedroom.
I'll have my secretary call her this afternoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to request you, as a manager, to either have someone fix the problem with the microwave or simply replace it. International English Language Testing System; C2; Ulithian

sense.def: to dislike someone and want to cause problems for them
dictionaryExamples: She really has it in for me - I don't know what I did to upset her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only then did she reali[z]e that somebody had it in for her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be in a stronger position than someone else so that you control a situation
dictionaryExamples: Government troops are gradually gaining the upper hand over the rebels.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Humans vs. machines - who has the upper hand? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

blocks.phrasalVerb: have on sth or have sth on

sense.def: If you have clothes or shoes on, you are wearing them.
dictionaryExamples: He's got a red shirt on.
I loved that dress you had on last night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I looked [over] my shoulder and there was Nora as white as the dress she had on. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

dictionaryExamples: He's got a red shirt on.

sense.def: something that is dangerous
dictionaryExamples: a fire hazard
a health hazard
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Like all things, mobile phones have advantages and disadvantages. [...] It is said that they produce cancer and that they are a health hazard. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: dangerous
dictionaryExamples: hazardous chemicals
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They are faced with hazardous chemical reactions when trying to gain new knowledge and therefore people should be very grateful to them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: used to refer to a man, boy, or male animal that has already been mentioned
dictionaryExamples: You can  ask Andrew - he may know.
Don't be scared! He's a very friendly dog.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He is from Hungary. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: the part of the body above the neck that contains your brain, eyes, nose, mouth, ears, etc., and on which your hair grows
dictionaryExamples: Put this hat on to keep your head warm.
He fell and hit his head on the table.
She nodded/shook her head.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You must wear a cap [on] your head. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: the person who is in charge of an organization or a part of an organization
dictionaryExamples: the head of an oil company
The head of our department is leaving on Friday.
He is the head chef at a  large restaurant.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Joshua was the head of security of the international airport of New York. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the mind and mental abilities
dictionaryExamples: All these thoughts were going through my head.
What put that (idea)into your head?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since I have never been there, I imagine all the places in my head. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to stop being calm in a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: I saw the fire and I lost my head.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She has never lost her head in dangerous s[i]tuations and she always knows what to do. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to remain calm in a difficult situation
dictionaryExamples: To be successful in business, you need to keep a cool head in negotiations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Kevin managed to keep a cool head and took over the navigation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to have just enough money to live or to continue a business
dictionaryExamples: With extra income from private sponsorship, the club is just about managing to keep its head above water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also started to reali[z]e how much she had on her plate, how very little help she had and how, at times, she had to struggle just like me to keep her head above water. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to laugh/shout/scream, etc., very much and very loudly
dictionaryExamples: The show was great! I laughed my head off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Other pupils were laughing their heads off as she went. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the front or top part of something
dictionaryExamples: Who is that at the head of the table?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There, at the head of the [line], her uncle with his two daughters waited for her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to move in a particular direction
dictionaryExamples: I was heading out of the room when she called me back.
He headed straight for  the refrigerator.
We were heading toward Orlando when our truck broke down.
I think we ought to head back/home  now, before it gets too dark.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I headed for the dining room. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to be in charge of a group, organization, etc.
dictionaryExamples: She heads a thriving software business.
Detective Kerry headed the investigation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When Carlos headed the government, the country [saw] important changes, such as Free Trade among Canada, USA and Mexico; the selling of the banks; "democratic" elections. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to be at the front or top of something
dictionaryExamples: Jo headed a very short list of candidates.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When it comes to money paid to the families, Germany headed the list with 2%, follow[ed] by Spain with 0.25% and the USA with 0.2%. International English Language Testing System; C1; Farsi

sense.def: to be likely to experience a bad situation soon
dictionaryExamples: They'll be heading for trouble if they're not careful.
The country is heading for a recession.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mankind is heading for the future sometimes faster than we think. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to start to leave a place or begin a trip, walk, etc.
dictionaryExamples: We'll head off after lunch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After being snowed in, the following morning we headed off to Las Vegas. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a pain you feel inside your head
dictionaryExamples: I have a splitting  headache.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He said he feel[s] sick and ha[s] [a] headache. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: words at the top of a piece of writing that tell you what it is about
dictionaryExamples: You'll find it under the heading 'Information for new students'.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As the advertis[e]ment included the heading "Come and discover the career of your dreams!", my attention was drawn to it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the title of a newspaper story that is printed in large letters above it
dictionaryExamples: a front-page headline
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The headline was "FAILURE OF FESTIVAL". First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: the main stories in newspapers, on television, etc.

sense.def: the place from where an organization is controlled

sense.def: If a wound or broken bone heals, it becomes healthy again, and if something heals it, it makes it healthy again.
dictionaryExamples: The wound on his head had begun to heal (up).

sense.def: the condition of your body

sense.def: physically strong and well

dictionaryExamples: a healthy diet

sense.def: a lot of something
dictionaryExamples: He has heaps of money.

International English Language Testing System; C2; German

sense.def: to be aware of a sound through your ears
dictionaryExamples: She heard a noise outside.

sense.def: to listen to someone or something
dictionaryExamples: I heard on the radio that it's going to rain.

sense.def: to be told some information

I hear (that) you're leaving.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After, she told me that my mother-in-law [had] arrived [in] the city and, obviously, when I heard that, I started to cry. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: the last time someone heard anything about someone or something

sense.def: If you hear from someone, you get a letter, a message, or a telephone call from them, or they tell you something.
dictionaryExamples: We haven't heard from her for a long time.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't hear from my friend for a long time. Preliminary English Test; B1; Romanian

sense.def: the organ in your chest that sends the blood around your body
dictionaryExamples: heart disease/failure
He has a weak/bad heart.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My father [is] going to have heart s[u]rgery. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: someone's deepest feelings and true character
dictionaryExamples: She has a kind heart.

sense.def: the center of something or the most important part of something
dictionaryExamples: Kansas City is in the heart of cattle country.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This restaurant is in the heart of Tepec, and it is open from 10.00am to 6.00pm except on Friday. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: a shape that represents a heart and is used to mean love
dictionaryExamples: The card had a big heart on the front.

sense.def: used to say that you feel something very strongly
dictionaryExamples: I thank you with all my heart.

sense.def: so that you can remember all of something
dictionaryExamples: She has read the stories so oftent that she knows them by heart.

sense.def: used to say what you really feel or think
dictionaryExamples: In his heart, he knew she was right.

sense.def: If something comes from the heart it is something you strongly feel or believe

sense.def: used to say what someone is really like

sense.def: to tell someone your secret thoughts and feelings

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

dictionaryExamples: At first he said he wouldn't help us, but he seems to have had a change of heart.

sense.def: a serious medical condition in which the heart does not get enough blood, causing great pain and often leading to death

sense.def: the system that keeps a building warm

sense.def: the quality of being hot or warm, or the temperature of something

sense.def: to make food hot so that it can be eaten

sense.def: according to some religions, the place where good people go when they die

sense.def: something very nice that gives you great pleasure

sense.def: large in amount or degree

heavy breathing

Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: If you do or say something with a heavy heart, you feel very sad or anxious
dictionaryExamples: It was with a heavy heart that he packed his bags and left his home of many years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I started to clear the table with a heavy heart, and was still in the process of washing up when the bell rang and, on dashing to open the door - I was the only one that was still up - I was relieved to find that my friends had come to greet me, as is their wont. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

blocks.phrase: here you are/here it is, etc.
