The papers were hidden under the floorboards.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lord Alloway hid the suitcase [to] protect it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to go to a place where you cannot be seen or found
dictionaryExamples: She ran off and hid behind a tree.
They hid themselves in the closet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The plan is to bring him to my house, [and] everybody [will] hide in the living room. [W]hen he enter[s] the room, we [will] shout 'Surprise'. Preliminary English Test; B1; Thai

sense.def: to keep a feeling or information secret
dictionaryExamples: He couldn't hide his embarrassment.
There's something about her past that she's trying to hide from me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I knew that you loved each other more than anything in this world, but I couldn't hide my surprise when you told me that you're getting married. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: using a system that arranges things according to their importance
dictionaryExamples: The company has a very hierarchical structure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, being too submissive will not help you in going up in a hierarchical structure. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a system or organization in which people or things are arranged according to their importance
dictionaryExamples: There is a very strict hierarchy where I work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is well known that clothes used to reflect the position that each individual had in the social hierarchy of our societies. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: having a large distance from the bottom to the top
dictionaryExamples: a high building/mountain
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And also you can see high mount[a]ins [and] beautiful lakes. Key English Test; A2; Hungarian

sense.def: a large distance above the ground or the level of the sea
dictionaryExamples: a high window
The town was high up in the mountains.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Look[ing] out [of] the window, I can see the birds high up on the trees. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: great in amount, size or level
dictionaryExamples: a high temperature
high prices/costs
The car sped away at high speed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Be careful while you are in Brazil because sometimes people charge really high prices for everything just because you are a tourist. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: very good
dictionaryExamples: high standards/quality
She always got high grades in science.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were lots of CD players and [everything] was high quality. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: important, powerful, or at the top level of something
dictionaryExamples: a high rank
Safety is our highest priority.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Living is definitely the highest priority [all] over the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: If a food is high in something, it contains a lot of it.
dictionaryExamples: Avoid foods that are high in salt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since there is no time even for cooking a healthy meal, they get used to ready meals that are high in fat and salt. International English Language Testing System; C1; Singhalese

sense.def: at or to a large distance above the ground
dictionaryExamples: We flew high above the city.
He threw the ball high into the air.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being in the cabin high above Vienna both of them th[ought] about killing the other. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: at or to a large amount or level
dictionaryExamples: Temperatures rose as high as 105 degrees in the summer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can we expect to see the world unemployment rate reach as high as fifty percent? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to emphasize something or make people notice something
dictionaryExamples: to highlight a problem/danger
The report highlights the need for stricter regulations.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Electricity in general has been absor[b]ed into our [daily] activities in such an intense way that we tend to take it for granted [a]nd it is exactly when it is not available that our dependency [o]n it is highlighted. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to make something a different color so that is is more easily noticed, especially written words
dictionaryExamples: The spelling mistakes in the text had been highlighted in yellow.

sense.def: the best or most important part of something
dictionaryExamples: The boat trip was one of the highlights of our vacation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Festival is one of the highlights of the year for me and many others. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: at a high level
dictionaryExamples: a highly paid job
a highly educated workforce
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am [a] 24-year-old highly educated Turkish boy. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: very or to a large degree
dictionaryExamples: a highly effective treatment
We are highly unlikely to meet anyone here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now it features a highly effective searching system. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: to have or express a very good opinion of someone or something
dictionaryExamples: The course is very highly thought of.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This in itself would speak highly of the school and will attract many candidates and parents. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: A high-profile person or event is known about by a lot of people and receives a lot of attention from television, newspapers, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a high-profile campaign/case
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is the main significant reason [why] sportsmen and sportswomen are now considered as high-profile celebrities. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a school for students aged between about 14 and 18
dictionaryExamples: Rory will be starting high school in September.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Jan, Peter and our friends from high school came to my party. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: using or involved with the most recent and advanced electronic machines, computers, etc.
dictionaryExamples: His new car has a high-tech sound system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can build up a high-tech computer lab, and last but not least, we can provide some talented students with scholarship[s]. First Certificate in English; B2; Farsi

sense.def: a public road, especially a long, wide, important road that joins cities or towns together  or that is used by traffic traveling long distances
dictionaryExamples: a coastal/interstate highway
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yesterday I heard that our gover[n]ment is going to build a bypass road around our city and connect it with the highway. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: the activity of going for a long walk for pleasure outdoors
dictionaryExamples: We're going hiking in the mountains this weekend.
a pair of hiking boots
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We will drive to a place in the mountains and go hiking to another place there. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: extremely funny
dictionaryExamples: They all thought the movie was hilarious.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition to this, the hosts and actors of the show have very few boundaries and are not afraid to make fools out of themselves, which means that they can do things that most people find very embar[ra]ssing, and this is something that contributes to making the show hilarious. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Norwegian

sense.def: a raised area of land, smaller than a mountain
dictionaryExamples: We walked up/down the hill to the village.
They climbed  the hill to get a better view.
Their house is on the top of a hill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can travel to Sierra de la Fentene, it is a nice village, [and] there are a lot of hills and streams. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used after a verb or preposition to refer to someone male who has already been talked about
dictionaryExamples: If you see Kevin, give him my love.
What's Jay up to? I haven't seen him in a long time.
We've just gotten a new cat, but we haven't named him yet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His name is Christopher but we all call him Hóby. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Portuguese

sense.def: the reflexive form of the pronoun "he"
dictionaryExamples: He cut himself shaving.
Most nights he would cry himself to sleep.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He woke up and the suitcase wasn't there... that day he thr[e]w himself from the 10th floor of a building. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: alone or without anyone else's help
dictionaryExamples: He built the house all by himself.
He lives by himself in a remote cabin.
Did he do all this work himself?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And Ramundo gave me one special T-shirt, because he made that by himself! Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to emphasize the pronoun "he" or the particular male person you are referring to
dictionaryExamples: Do you want to talk to my brother himself, or can I help you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But no one would like to be behind bars himself. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to make it difficult to do something or for something to develop
dictionaryExamples: His performance at the Olympics was hindered by a knee injury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nothing, however, could hinder him from gaining more power and money. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: when you say something that suggests what you think or want, but not in a direct way
dictionaryExamples: He's dropped  several hints to the boss that he'll quit if he doesn't get a promotion.
Did she give you any hints about where she was going?
You can't take  a hint, can you? Just go away and leave me alone!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He didn't take a hint. When that day had come, I timidly approached him and [gave] him my [final] words [of] warning. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a small piece of advice
dictionaryExamples: The magazine gives lots of useful hints on how to save money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to make use of this offer, therefore I am writing down [some] helpful hints about Lampton. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a small amount of something
dictionaryExamples: There was a hint of anger in her voice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sky was leaden and overcast and there was a hint of drizzle in the air. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: one of the two parts of your body above your leg and below your waist
dictionaryExamples: She stood waiting with her hands on her hips.
This exercise is designed to trim your hips and stomach.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had a fractured ankle, a dis[locat]ed collar-bone and something was also wrong with her hips. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a kind of music that originally developed among African Americans, where the words to songs are spoken and not sung
dictionaryExamples: The station plays mainly hip-hop and R&B music.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nick, I like hip hop and rock very much and most of the students agree with me. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to begin to to employ someone
dictionaryExamples: I was hired by the first company I applied to.
We ought to hire a public relations consultant to help improve our image.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The interview was OK and my friend and I w[ere] hired! First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: belonging to or relating to someone male who has already been talked about
dictionaryExamples: Alex is sitting over there with his daughter.
It's not his fault.
"Jana has  a new boyfriend." "Oh, really? What's his name?"
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like his cooking [very much]. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Slovak

sense.def: the things that belong or relate to someone male who has already been talked about
dictionaryExamples: That's Frank's coat over there - at least I think it's his.
I borrowed them from a friend ofhis.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When he looked at the suitcase carefully, he realised it wasn't his. Preliminary English Test; B1; Malayalam

sense.def: someone who writes about or studies history
dictionaryExamples: His father was a famous historian.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would be very willing to help historians solve the enigma about the origin of Thailand. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Thai

sense.def: important or likely to be important in history
dictionaryExamples: historic buildings
a historic day/moment
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know you and I understand that you [are coming to] my country to visit ancient castle[s] and historic buildings, so I recommend [you] to visit Rome: a fantastic city! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: relating to events or people in the past, or to the study of history
dictionaryExamples: Many important historical documents were destroyed when the library was bombed.
She specializes in historical novels set in eighteenth-century England.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Budapest is very beautiful with a [lot] of historical buildings and churches. Preliminary English Test; B1; Hungarian

sense.def: in a way that is connected to history
dictionaryExamples: The film makes no attempt to be historically accurate.

Historically, there have always
                         been close links between France and Scotland.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, maybe this brief description of my travel in time is not historically accurate; nevertheless I hope that you have enjoyed yourself reading it as much as I did writing it, and I hope you will consider it worth[y] of publication in your magazine. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: the whole series of events in the past that relate to the development of a country, subject, or person
dictionaryExamples: The Civil War was a terrible time in American history.
What do you know about the history of jazz?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I liked it very much because it [was] about Chinese history. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the study of events in the past
dictionaryExamples: He's very interested in modern European history.
a history book
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Nicolas, I think I left my history book in your house. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: If you have a history of a particular problem or illness, you have already suffered from it.
dictionaryExamples: Our family has a history of diabetes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The characteristic we are born with is to a certain level affected by genetic factor[s], e.g., if a mother has a history of depression her daughter or son will also have higher chance [of] get[ting] depression. International English Language Testing System; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to touch someone or something quickly and with force using your hand or an object in your hand
dictionaryExamples: She hit him on the head with her tennis racket.
Teachers are not allowed to hit their students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I went in, somebody hit me with a pan! Preliminary English Test; B1; Arabic

sense.def: to touch someone or something quickly and with force, usually causing injury or damage
dictionaryExamples: The car went out of control and hit a wall.
She hit her head on the sidewalk when she fell.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He hit a boy on the main road [but] fortun[ate]ly the boy was ok[a]y. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: to affect something badly
dictionaryExamples: The economy has been hit by high unemployment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Penalties for parking in [the] wrong place can really hit you in [the] po[c]ket. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to reach a place, position, or state
dictionaryExamples: Our profits have already hit $1 million.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having already hit the 50% boundary in 1991, we still see that the teachers' salaries experienced a significant rise. International English Language Testing System; C1; German

sense.def: If an idea or thought hits you, you suddenly think of it.
dictionaryExamples: The idea for the book hit me in the middle of the night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I climbed out of the shower, staggered into my room and then it hit me! "My diary! For crying out loud, that's it!" Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: If people hit it off, they like each other and become friendly immediately.
dictionaryExamples: Carla and Nina didn't really hit it off.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They hit it off immediately. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a thing or person that is very popular or successful
dictionaryExamples: The Beatles had a string of number-one hits in the 1960s.
Your cake was a real hit at the party - everyone loved it.
They just released a CD of their greatest hits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The group RADIANT played their big hits [from the] 1980s for an hour. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: a request to see a document on the Internet that is then counted to calculate the number of people looking at the page
dictionaryExamples: There have been over 10,000 hits on the site since Wednesday.

sense.def: to get free rides in someone's vehicle, by standing next to the road and waiting for someone to pick you up
dictionaryExamples: We hitchhiked from Chicago to New Orleans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We hitchhike[d] to the nearest city. Preliminary English Test; B1; Polish

sense.def: using or involved with the most recent and advanced electronic machines, computers, etc.
dictionaryExamples: This database system is an affordable, hi-tech solution.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With the development of science and technology, many new inve[ntions] have entered our life, especially some hi-tech products. International English Language Testing System; B2; Chinese

sense.def: an activity that you enjoy and do regularly when you are not working
dictionaryExamples: Ben's hobby is restoring old motorcycles.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My hobby is playing the guitar. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a game played on ice in which two teams try to hit a small hard object into a goal using long curved sticks
dictionaryExamples: We skate or play hockey with the kids' friends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I just watched the hockey game with Newsha. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: to have something in your hand or arms
dictionaryExamples: He was holding a glass of wine.
She held the baby in her arms.
They were holding hands and kissing.
Can you hold the bag while I open the door?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like to hold [the cat] tightly because her [fur] is so soft and lovely.  Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: to keep something in a particular position
dictionaryExamples: Can you hold the door open, please?
Hold your hand up if you know the answer.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I looked [at] the letter again and now I understood why I didn't understand anything. I held it up side down, so I couldn't read it. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to organize an event
dictionaryExamples: to hold talks/an election
A music festival is held there in July.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every evening the concerts are held in the open air, so you can have lots of fun. Preliminary English Test; B1; Croatian

sense.def: to contain or be able to contain something
dictionaryExamples: This pitcher holds up to  two quarts.
Don't pack more than one suitcase will hold.
Computers can hold huge amounts of information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Big companies which hold a huge amount of information would not be able to work without a computer. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to keep someone in a place so that they cannot leave
dictionaryExamples: The terrorists held him hostage for 18 months.
I was held prisoner in a tiny attic room.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All around the world animals are held as prisoners in zoos.  First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: to keep air in your lungs and not let it out
dictionaryExamples: How long can you hold your breath under water?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My heart was beating fast. I was holding my breath. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to have a particular position in a competition
dictionaryExamples: to hold the world record
The team held the lead until the 89th minute.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays she is an excellent sportswoman, she holds the world record. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to have a particular job, position, diploma, etc.
dictionaryExamples: He currently holds the position of managing editor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact 90% males hold the skilled vocational diploma where[as] only 10% females hold the same degree. International English Language Testing System; C1; Arabic

sense.def: to believe something
dictionaryExamples: He holds unpopular views on many subjects.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, some people hold the opinion that children who do not have good living conditions are better prepared to deal with the problems which they will encounter later on. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to have a conversation
dictionaryExamples: I can just about hold a conversation in Italian.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know the grammar and many different expressions, and I can hold a conversation with other people. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to keep someone interested in something
dictionaryExamples: The movie held my attention from beginning to end.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The plot is so intricately constr[u]cted that it will not only hold your attention right up to the last page, but also last in your memory for a very long time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: to wait for something to happen, often feeling anxious
dictionaryExamples: While the leaders negotiated, the world held its breath.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They, the critics, the fans and friends and his wife, held their breath and crossed their fingers, hoping to once again hear his enchanting voice. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to be as successful as other people or things
dictionaryExamples: Alison could always hold her own in political debates.

sense.def: If you say that an argument doesn't hold water, you mean that it can't be true.
dictionaryExamples: The jury convicted her because her story just didn’t hold water.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  It remains to us to prove that the opinions of some scientists are far-fetched and don't hold water. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to like or respect someone less because they have done something wrong or behaved badly
dictionaryExamples: It was his mistake but I won't hold it against him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When my Dad was about sixteen, he had to get a job. [...] My uncle on the other hand was al[lowe]d to study until he was 21. They have never held it against each other, as far as I know. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: to prevent someone or something from moving forward
dictionaryExamples: The police held back the protesters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At last, the guards were able to temporarily hold them back. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: to prevent someone or something from making progress
dictionaryExamples: She felt staying in the same job would hold her back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For years, nothing could hold her back, and she didn't realize how her huge amount of self-confidence prevented her from seeing life as it really was. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

blocks.phrasalVerb: hold back sth or hold sth back

sense.def: to not tell everything you know about something
dictionaryExamples: I think she suspected I was holding something back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To be honest, I am holding back a lot more things special about the cottage, because I want you to come and have a look. International English Language Testing System; C1; Malayalam

sense.def: to stop yourself from showing an emotion
dictionaryExamples: She couldn't hold back the tears.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the last scenes, I could not hold back my tears any longer and I just burst into tears. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to keep a job
dictionaryExamples: It can be difficult for a mother to hold down a full-time job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't know how long I'd manage to hold down a job that I d[id]n't like, and that d[id]n't bring me anything other than money. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to wait before doing something
dictionaryExamples: We'll hold off making a decision until we hear from Nick.

sense.def: to wait for a short time
dictionaryExamples: Hold on - I have another call coming in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've a lot of good stories to tell you about so hold on. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: something you say when you are confused or surprised by something that you have just heard or read and want to understand it
dictionaryExamples: Hold on, if Sara's not coming, why are we asking for a table for six?

sense.def: to hold something firmly or to keep something
dictionaryExamples: Hold onto the rope and don't let go.
The team held onto first place with a 4-3 win last night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I take my poetry book with me all the time to hold onto something so important to me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to think that something is likely to succeed or have a good result
dictionaryExamples: Few people hold out any hope of finding more survivors of the earthquake.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To be honest, I don't hold out much hope that this problem will ever be solved, because homelessness doesn't affect MPs personally. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

blocks.phrasalVerb:
hold
                up sb/sth or hold sb/sth up

sense.def: to make something or someone slow or late
dictionaryExamples: We got held up by the traffic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I was held up in a traffic jam. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when you hold something or someone, or the way you do this
dictionaryExamples: Keep a tight hold on your tickets.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I got up on my feet again, I reached out my arm to get a hold on something, but there w[as]n't anything to hold on to. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to start holding something or someone
dictionaryExamples: He took hold of one end of the rug and tugged.
I just managed to grab hold of Lucy before she fell in the pool.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "I'm scared!" said Nora trembling, as she took hold of my arm. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to obtain something, or to manage to speak to someone
dictionaryExamples: I got hold of a copy at the library.
I called three times, but couldn't get hold of her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had also forgotten to remind my friends and teachers to bring their own knife and fork to our lunch, but fortunately one of my friends managed to get hold of some spare knives and forks. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: If a plan or activity is on hold, it will not be done until a later time.
dictionaryExamples: The project is on hold until we raise more money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What's more, it might, intentional[l]y or not, raise awareness on issues that might have been put on hold by authorities, such as the legalization of soft drugs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: waiting to speak to someone on the telephone
dictionaryExamples: His secretary put me on hold.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The day after, I called your office and after being put on hold, the person answering the phone was unwilling to come up with a proper reply. International English Language Testing System; C1; Dutch

sense.def: power or control over something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Their company has a strong hold on the computer market.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They send the money directly to his father and now have a hold on Chen. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a hollow space in something, or an opening in a surface
dictionaryExamples: a bullet hole
There's a hole  in the roof.
We dug a hole to plant the tree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like wearing jeans with holes in them, they look cool. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: a day for celebration when many people are allowed to stay away from work or school
dictionaryExamples: a national holiday
the Fourth of July holiday
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a holiday for us. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: having a hole or empty space inside
dictionaryExamples: a hollow shell/tube
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He had taken the dark red leather-bound book to his hideout in the forest, an old oak tree with a hollow trunk, where he used to play alone. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: without meaning or real feeling
dictionaryExamples: a hollow victory
a hollow laugh
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These celebrities tend to encourage a lifestyle that, at first, may be extremely appealing, specially to children and teenagers, but it is nothing [more] than pure hollow hedonism. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If something someone says rings hollow, it does not sound true or sincere.
dictionaryExamples: He said he was pleased, but his words rang hollow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everything rang hollow to her, so she decided to follow him in order to understand what had happened and her fiancé became so friendly and understanding. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: relating to a religion or a god
dictionaryExamples: the holy city of Jerusalem
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'd like to go inside and see for myself but only the holy priests are allowed to be in there and only [on] special occasions. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: the place where you live or feel you belong
dictionaryExamples: I tried to call him, but he wasn't at home.
We sold our home in Dallas and moved to Atlanta.

He left 
                          home when he was eighteen.
I was actually born in New Zealand, but I've lived in England for so long that it feels like home now.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That's why I love my home. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to feel happy and confident in a place or situation
dictionaryExamples: After a month she felt at home in her new job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I explained: "I was in Manchester for just 10 month[s] and [during] that time the people from there made me feel at home [so] I feel proud to have the accent." Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the place where you usually find something or someone, or where they come from
dictionaryExamples: France, the home of good food
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every golfer - and those watching golf - know, that the home of golf is St. Andrews in Scotland. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: to behave in a relaxed way in a place, as if it was your own home
dictionaryExamples: Take off your coat and make yourself at home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please relax and make yourself at home and help yourself. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: a place where a group of people who need special care live
dictionaryExamples: a nursing home
My grandmother lives in a home now.

sense.def: to the place where you live

sense.def: without a place to live

sense.def: people who are homeless

sense.def: the state of being homeless
dictionaryExamples: The government is trying to tackle homelessness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unemployment is a major problem today and it leads more and more people on[to] the path of poverty and homelessness. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: work that teachers give students to do at home

dictionaryExamples: To be honest, I didn't really enjoy the party.

sense.def: the quality of being honest

sense.def: a sweet, sticky food that is made by bees
dictionaryExamples: Tea with honey and lemon is good for a sore throat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For breakfast they eat bread with butter, jam or honey. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Slovak

sense.def: a vacation taken by two people who have just gotten married
dictionaryExamples: We went to the Bahamas on our honeymoon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Where did you spend your honeymoon? Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian

sense.def: in order to celebrate or show respect for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: a banquet in honor of the president
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally we went to Corinth, where there are a lot of ancient sanctuaries which were built in hon[o]r of their gods. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: proud and pleased because you have been given respect or asked to do something special
dictionaryExamples: I am honored to accept your invitation.

sense.def: part of a piece of clothing that can be pulled up to cover the top and back of the head

sense.def: a curved piece of metal or plastic used for hanging something on, or a similar object used for catching fish

a boat hook
a fish hook

sense.def: to like or start to like doing something very much and want to do it all the time

sense.def: to go somewhere quickly or get into or out of a vehicle quickly

sense.def: to jump on one foot or to move about in this way

sense.def: If a small animal, bird, or insect hops, it moves by jumping on all of its feet at the same time.

sense.def: to want something to happen or be true
dictionaryExamples: I hope (that) the bus won't be late.

"Is he coming?" "I hope so."

sense.def: to intend to do something
dictionaryExamples: Dad hopes to retire next year.

sense.def: a positive feeling about the future, or something that you want to happen or be true
dictionaryExamples: a message full of hope

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ten minutes later I started to tell [them] how brave [they were] and how we fought when there was no hope. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: because you want something good to happen
dictionaryExamples: She went to Paris in the hope of improving her French.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Dave Bennington, I am writing to you in the hope that you will attend our next event in July. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

dictionaryExamples: He was hopeful about the outcome of the meeting.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know that it is quite impossible to find it [i]n a big town like mine, but I am [still] hopeful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

dictionaryExamples: There are hopeful signs that she will make a full recovery.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The hopeful atmosphere darkened somewhat. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

dictionaryExamples: Hopefully it won't rain.

sense.def: in a hopeful way

sense.def: without hope

sense.def: very bad at a particular activity
dictionaryExamples: I'm hopeless at sports.

sense.def: extremely, or in a way that makes you lose hope

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's never easy to be young and hopelessly in love. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: level and flat, or parallel to the ground or to the bottom of a page

sense.def: a piece of equipment used to make a loud sound as a warning or signal

dictionaryExamples: He has a horrible cold.

a horse and cart

hotel guests

Trains leave every hour on the hour.

dictionaryExamples: an hourly rate
hourly pay
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'll also call the shop and ask [about] the hourly rate and the working hours. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

to buy/rent a house

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Come to my house for dinner tomorrow. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Turkish

sense.def: the people watching a performance or the area where they sit
dictionaryExamples: The actors played to a full house.

sense.def: to provide space for something

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her study houses a really huge collection of books on history, architecture, [and] geography of the places we have been to. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

household chores
household expenses

sense.def: a woman whose work is inside the home, doing the cleaning, cooking, etc., and who usually does not have any other job

sense.def: buildings for people to live in
dictionaryExamples: a shortage of affordable housing
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many trees have been cut in order to make roads or used for housing and making furniture. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Basque

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will be very happy to go fishing and swimming in the lake like the last time.  However, if you don't want to do it, it's not a problem for me. Key English Test; A2; French

dictionaryExamples: We're not going to get there in time, however fast we drive.

sense.def: in whatever way

She sat on the floor hugging her knees.

sense.def: when you put your arms around someone and hold them tightly
dictionaryExamples: Come here and give me a big hug.
We always exchange hugs and kisses when we meet.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The singer of the band ,"Green Day" was coming to[wards] me. [He] took my hand and then gave me a hug. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: extremely large
dictionaryExamples: They live in a huge house.

A huge number of people attended.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I live in a huge old house in the suburbs with my family. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to sing without opening your mouth

sense.def: relating to people or their characteristics

human behavior

sense.def: to not be perfect

sense.def: a man, woman or child
dictionaryExamples: The greatest damage being done to our planet today is that being done by humans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't believe that people want to hurt each other for money and power but this has happened all the time in the history of human being[s]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: connected with improving people's lives and reducing suffering
dictionaryExamples: The UN is sending humanitarian aid to the refugees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Indeed, the conflicts in the Balkans are so deeply rooted and complex that they can be likened to a political quagmire: once you go in, a withdrawal of humanitarian aid and military forces becomes difficult to undertake. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: all people
dictionaryExamples: The massacre was a crime against humanity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All humanity enjoys the numerous advances in modern technology and [in] our day,  life [has become] more interesting and eas[ier]. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: kindness and sympathy toward others
dictionaryExamples: Mother Teresa was famous for her compassion and humanity.

sense.def: the basic rights that every person should have, such as justice and freedom to say what you think

sense.def: not proud or not believing that you are important
dictionaryExamples: He's very humble about his success.

dictionaryExamples: It's very humid today.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] north of Iran is wet but [the] south of Iran is humid and hot. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: made to feel stupid or ashamed
dictionaryExamples: She felt completely humiliated.

sense.def: making you feel stupid or ashamed
dictionaryExamples: a humiliating defeat
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How humiliating it had been to have her parental abilities questioned. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: the quality of not being proud or not thinking that you are better than other people
dictionaryExamples: Try to show a little humility.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This growing shopping mania is also said to create an increasingly materialistic society; hence, our children grow up forgetting the basic values of life - simplicity, integrity, humility and plain hard work. International English Language Testing System; C2; Chinese

sense.def: funny, or making you laugh
dictionaryExamples: a humorous book
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To be more specific, the articles will include events taken from our college life, written in a humorous, chatty way. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the number 100
dictionaryExamples: We've driven a/one hundred miles in the last two hours.
"How many kids are there in the school?" "About three hundred."
That dress costs hundreds of dollars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It cost nine hundred yuan at least. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: the feeling you have when you need to eat or have not eaten enough
dictionaryExamples: Drinks don't satisfy your hunger the way solid food does.
By about 9 o'clock she started to feel faint from/with hunger.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It [wa]s [what] I expected, a baby crying f[rom] hunger. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: when you do not have enough food
dictionaryExamples: All over the world, people die of hunger every day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many changes are coming and many problems are coming too, because overpopulation, contamination, pollution, hunger, [and] poverty besides come with this technological revolution and that is something that the human being will have to solve soon. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a strong wish for something
dictionaryExamples: a hunger for knowledge/adventure
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The most important factor when learning English is the hunger for knowledge, the hunger for the unknown. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: wanting or needing food
dictionaryExamples: By four o'clock I felt/was really hungry.
The boys are always hungry  when they get home from school.
She often goes hungry herself  so that her children can have enough to eat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  I'm very happy [about] this dinner, because after w[or]k I'm so hungry. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to have a strong wish for something
dictionaryExamples: The journalists were hungry for more details of the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am always fascinated with people who are well-educated and do not stop being hungry for information. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to chase and kill wild animals
dictionaryExamples: Some animals hunt at night.
Cats like to hunt mice and birds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I was saying, you can also go to jungle hotels - comfortable hotels in the middle of the forest, just crossing the Amazon River, where you can keep in touch with nature, feed monkeys and even "hunt" alligators (all sizes, believe me!). Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to search for something or someone
dictionaryExamples: I've hunted all over the place, but I can't find that book.
They are still hunting for the missing child.
I've hunted high and lowfor my gloves.
Police are hunting the terrorists who planted the bomb.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You don't have to hunt for a place to park your car and to worry what will happen when you're out of gas. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a search for something or someone
dictionaryExamples: After a long hunt we finally found a house we liked.
The hunt for the injured climber continued throughout the night.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What is more, it helps to face problems which could occur during the hunt for a "lifetime" job. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: the sport of chasing and killing animals
dictionaryExamples: deer hunting
She's completely against hunting of any kind.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And of course hunting won't be allowed. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to move or do things more quickly than normal, or to make someone do this
dictionaryExamples: Hurry, or you'll be late.
She hurried to answer the phone.
I'm sorry to hurry you, but I have to leave in a few minutes.
After spending her lunch hour shopping, she hurried back  to work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I will start painting at 3:45 pm [but] you don't have to hurry. Key English Test; A2; Thai

sense.def: to do something more quickly
dictionaryExamples: Hurry up, or we'll miss the bus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I woke up at 9 a.m. I had to hurry up because my flight was at 11 a.m. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

blocks.phrasalVerb: hurry up sb/sth or hurry sb/sth up

sense.def: to make someone do something more quickly, or to make something happen sooner
dictionaryExamples: Can't you hurry the kids up so we can get there on time?
What he did was to hurry up the process.

sense.def: the need to move or do things more quickly than normal
dictionaryExamples: We left in such a hurry that we forgot our tickets.
"Can you wait a few minutes?" "Yes, I'm not in any hurry/I'm in no hurry."
Are you in a hurry  to leave?
What's (all) the hurry (for)/Why (all) the hurry? We have plenty of time.
"I'll give this back to you next week." "That's all right, there's no (great) hurry/there isn't any (great) hurry ."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maybe she was nervous or in a hurry and wrote my e-mail adress instead of his. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to cause pain
dictionaryExamples: Sam hurt his knee playing football.
Beth hurt herself when she fell off her bike.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hurt myself one week ago so I can't help you. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: If a part of your body hurts, it feels painful.
dictionaryExamples: My eyes really hurt.
It hurts to walk on it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'[m going to] see the dentist, because my tooth is hurting and I really need to go. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to cause emotional pain to someone
dictionaryExamples: She called me stupid and fat, and that really hurt.
He was badly hurt by the end of his marriage.
I didn't mean to hurt your feelings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My heart was hurt and nobody will [be able to] repair the damage. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: injured or in pain
dictionaryExamples: Let me help you up. Are you hurt?
Put that knife away before someone gets hurt.
Several people were seriously/badly hurt in the explosion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me: "Your father got hurt in [a] traffic accident!" Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: upset or unhappy
dictionaryExamples: I feel very hurt by what you said.
"That was really mean," he said in a hurt voice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I know you got very hurt when [you and] Brian broke up. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: the man a woman is married to
dictionaryExamples: I've never met Fiona's husband.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On Sunday afternoon[s], she goes with her husband and her son to the swi[m]ming pool. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Russian

sense.def: a small, simple building, often made of wood
dictionaryExamples: a mountain hut
a row of beach huts
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, we reached a hut near a river, where we stayed until the following day, when we returned home by bus. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the process of keeping things clean, especially to prevent disease
dictionaryExamples: health and hygiene regulations
dental/personal hygiene
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The ones that need medical services at home have hardly [got] anyone, and no one has helped them with personal hygiene. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: very clean, so that bacteria cannot spread
dictionaryExamples: hygienic conditions
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: That was not only extremely uncomfortable, but also inconvenient and not very hygienic. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: a mark (-) used to join two words together, or to show that a word has been divided and continues on the next line
dictionaryExamples: There should be a hyphen in "high-tech."

sense.def: when someone pretends to believe something that they do not really believe or that is the opposite of what they do or say at another time
dictionaryExamples: I can't stand their hypocrisy - they say they care about the poor but then they go home and drink champagne.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would recommend Hartley's novel to people who would like to see the world once more from the point of view of a child: a world too strange, too full of hypocrisy and egotism to be understood by a boy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: Hypocritical people pretend to believe things that they do not really believe or that are the opposite of what they do or say at another time.
dictionaryExamples: Having told Tom that he should not accept any money from her, it would be rather hypocritical if I did.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One unique thought haunted her: go away from the environment she was living in and which she couldn't stand: the four-hour teas, the incessant discussions about Mrs X who was pregnant and Mr X who had lost his fortune in a game, the hypocritical smiles, the narrow-minded people blinded by money... all those details which enraged Lucy. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: a suggested explanation for something which has not yet been proved to be true
dictionaryExamples: They are investigating the hypothesis that obesity may be caused by a virus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first impression that comes to my mind is that when you live longer, you gain more experience and wisdom, which you can convey to your children, therefore the society becomes more experienced, responsible etc. (unfortunately, [real life] does not back up this hypothesis). Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If someone is hysterical, they cannot control their feelings or behavior because they are extremely frightened, angry, excited, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Calm down, you're getting hysterical.
She broke into hysterical laughter.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I became hysterical and started shouting at him. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch
